thread.title: Google Doodle commemorates Annie Besant on her 169th birth anniversary
thread.title_full: Google Doodle commemorates Annie Besant on her 169th birth anniversary

author: Mohammed Uzair Shaikh
title: Google Doodle commemorates Annie Besant on her 169th birth anniversary
text:
Google Doodle commemorates Annie Besant on her 169th birth anniversary By Mohammed Uzair Shaikh on October 1, 2015 at 2:41 AM Comments 
Google Doodle pays homage to civil rights’ activist Annie Besant on her 169th birth anniversary. The Britain-born humanist, significantly contributed in the Indian struggle of self-determination before the Gandhian era. 
Besant was born in London on October 1, 1847. Her stature as an anti-establishment leader grew when she led the Fabian Society and the Marxist Social Democratic Foundation in the 1880s’. She was one of the leading voices in Britain demanding home-rule for Ireland and India. (ALSO READ: When is Google’s birthday? Google Doodle celebrates 17 years of the search engine ) 
To guide the Indian National Congress, which was still struggling to make a mark for itself under the British Raj, Besant migrated to India in 1905. She was a staunch supporter of Bal Gangadhar Tilak and severely criticised the colonial administration for sentencing Tilak of six years of rigorous punishment for writing against the establishment. In 1914, she founded the All India Home Rule League demanding a separate dominion status for India within the British empire. 
Her stint socio-political activist in India lasted for almost three decades. She breathed her last in Adyar district for Madras. Besant is reminisced for her courageous struggle against injustice afflicted on the native citizen during the British rule.
